STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 27, 2020
Michael Cooper
St Vincent Catholic Charities-Child Welfare
2800 West Willow
Lansing, MI 48917
RE: License #: CB330201019
St Vincent Catholic Charities-Child Welfare
2800 West Willow
Lansing, MI 48917
Dear Mr. Cooper:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 3/9/2020.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Implementation, Sustainability, and Exit Plan (ISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 For any repeat violations, include an assessment of why the previous
corrective action plan was ineffective.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Rorie Dodge-Garnaat, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
235 Grand, Ste 1305
P.O. Box 30650
Lansing, MI 48909
(517) 899-6024
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
2 of 9 employee files reviewed did not have evaluations as required by the rule.
R 400.12328 Foster home record.
(1) An agency shall maintain a foster home record for each
foster home.
1 of 1 enrolled home reviewed, the agency reported they could not locate the file for
the home and this led to a delay in contacts after a licensing worker left.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months before
placement or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after placement.
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
(ii) 1 of 3 applicable foster care files did not have an initial physical
(iii) 1 of 3 applicable foster care files did not have a yearly physical completed
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
4

(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behavioral problems of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy
environment for the foster child and the foster family,
including information about siblings who do not reside in
the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency
medical care.
2 of 4 applicable foster care files did not have a document indicating the above
information was provided to the placement.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Renewal Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 5/1/19.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
3 of 8 foster care files had late Updated Service Plans
 2 of 3 were 1 day late
 1 of 3 was 7 days late
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Renewal Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 5/1/19.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for adoption.
5

1 of 3 Adoption Family files reviewed had a late evaluation. The application was
signed on 12/4/18 and the evaluation was completed on 12/4/19.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Renewal Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 5/1/19.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included
in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-05 Case Documentation:
MDHHS and PAFC providers must maintain all case
documentation in the child's electronic case record in
MiSACWIS.
5 of 6 foster care files reviewed did not have all documents uploaded into
MiSACWIS.
3 of 6 adoption case files reviewed did not have all documents uploaded into
MiSACWIS.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Renewal Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 5/1/19.
FOM 722-03 DHHS-69 Required for placement change
1 of 6 foster care files reviewed did not have a completed 69 for a placement change
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Renewal Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 5/1/19.
FOM 801 Medical Passports
6

5 of 6 foster care files reviewed did not have quarterly medical passports in the files.
FOM 722-08 Supervisory Approval ISP:
the caseworker’s supervisor must review, approve, and sign the
initial service plan within fourteen days, after a face to face
meeting with the caseworker.
2 of 2 applicable foster care files reviewed had late approvals of ISP’s
 1 of 2 was 8 days late
 1 of 2 was 28 days late
FOM 722-09 Supervisory Approval USP:
the caseworker’s supervisor must review, approve, and sign the
updated service plan within fourteen days, after a face to face
meeting with the caseworker.
2 of 6 foster care files reviewed had late approvals of USP’s
 1 of 2 had 1 report approved 1 day late
 1 of 2 had 2 reports approved 12 days late
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Renewal Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 5/1/19.
FOM 722-08C Required Participation in Development - Foster Parent /
Caregiver:
The foster parent is required to sign each Parent Agency
Treatment Plan
3 of 6 foster care files reviewed did not have caregiver signatures for service plans
 1 of 3 files did not have a caregiver’s signature on 3 of the reports reviewed
 1 of 3 files did not have the caregiver’s signature on 2 of the reports reviewed
 1 of 3 files did not have the caregiver’s signature on 1 of the reports reviewed
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Renewal Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 5/1/19.
FOM 722-08C Required Participation in Development
Parents and Youth over 14-Years Old: The parents and a child
over 14 are required to sign each Parent Agency Treatment
Plan
7

2 of 6 foster care files reviewed did not have parents’ signatures for service plans
 1 of 2 files did not have a parent’s signature on 3 of the reports reviewed
 1 of 2 files did not have a parent’s signature on 1 of the reports reviewed
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Renewal Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 5/1/19.
FOM 722-06H CASEWORKER CONTACT CHILD IN OUT-OF-HOME
PLACEMENT:
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
per month with the child for the first two months following an
initial placement or a placement move. The first face-to-face
contact with the child must take place within five business days
from the date the case is assigned to the caseworker or within
five business days of the date of the placement move.
2 of 6 foster care files reviewed did not have 2 face to face contacts in the first 2
months of an initial placement or a placement change.
FOM 722-06H TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER CONTACTS
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS within
five business days of the contact.
5 of 6 foster care files reviewed had contacts that were entered late.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Renewal Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 5/1/19.
FOM 722-6B FTM documentation:
Was a DHHS 1105 Completed after every FTM and placed in
MiSACWIS within 7 days?
3 of 6 foster care files reviewed did not have documentation for FTM’s
ADM 330 Quarterly Adoption Progress Reports
3 of 6 adoptive placement files reviewed did not have all of the quarterly progress
reports completed.
8

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 The agency should complete deferred Adoptive Family Evaluations if they
cannot obtain all of the necessary documentation timely.
 It is recommended that the agency work on ways to maintain continuity in
licensing of foster homes when there is a change in licensing workers.
 When a licensed foster home is referred to the agency for adoption obtain
documentation that PRIDE was completed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not require consultation at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
AND
The agency was not required to submit any corrective action plans during this
licensing period.
VII. Summary of Analyst Findings
During her visits the Foster Home Analyst, Kristen LaClair-Helmuth, found that on
1/23/20 Unlicensed Relative A did not have covers for one light switch and two
outlets. The agency responded by completing a home visit on 1/27/20 to ensure the
covers were installed. Pictures were taken to verify they were in place.
None of the other licensed and non-licensed homes had any safety alerts. All service
concerns brought up by the homes visited were discussed during the entrance
conference with agency management.
9

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
3/17/20
________________________________________
Rorie Dodge-Garnaat Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 27, 2020

Area Manager
